commit_message:
GCE-API Standalone service.

Change-Id: I6d3973177ed4e842672bc141f54fe9f15bf130be
Implements: blueprint gce-api
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/54/149654/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== GCE API service ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/Nova/+spec/gce-api This project provides a GCE API service separate from Nova which allows usage of GCE API for controlling OpenStack clouds. Problem description =================== Global purpose of this functionality is to support compatibility with GCE API protocol of Google. Nova supports now only a subset of Amazon's EC2 API protocol and provides no Google API support. Sister project for standalone EC2 API is also created and the spec for it is here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/147882 Use Cases ---------- User wants to use Google's GCE API to access OpenStack. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== It so happenned that the project in question is already implemented and is present here: https://github.com/stackforge/gce-api It was created earlier to be used in proprietary clouds to provide compatibility with GCE API. The whole functionality can be logically divided to 2 pieces: 1. Infrastructural functionality comprising the service, WSGI and alike. 2. GCE specific functionality APIs and controllers The following decisions where used for implementation of the above: 1. Nova's WSGI service and infrastructural code was taken and cleaned up to contain only necessary code for support of this standalone EC2 service. 2. GCE API functionality is implemented by pair of classes for each functional piece: API and Controller. First one implements the logic. Second one does the in and out parsing and formatting. Services: The project brings one new service - GCE API service. Functionality files: gceapi/api contains all of the APIs, Controllers and base functionality for them. For example, disk.py is the Controller, disk_api.py is the API for disk-related functionality. In case of differences arising because of Neutron or Nova-network, two API implementations are provided, like network_api.py with network_neutron_api.py and network_nova_api.py. Alternatives ------------ The only alternative was to integrate all of it into existing Nova EC2 layer which upon talks during Havana cycle was rejected. Data model impact ----------------- New Database and Datamodel is employed by this service. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Specific configuration options are brought by this project and are configured in gce-api.conf file. Provided install.sh script uses nova configuration to acquire some values so the script works if run on the same node which accommodates nova-api. Developer impact ---------------- Initial understanding reached during Kilo design summit with Nova core group and PTL was that if accepted this service will stay as a part of OpenStack Compute project. It is not clear what will happen with the core group of current stackforge project during this process. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Alexandre Levine (alexandrelevine) Other contributors: Feodor Tersin (ftersin), Andrey Pavlov (apavlov-e) Work Items ---------- The feature is already done and lives here: https://github.com/stackforge/gce-api Remaining tasks: 1. Somewhat later bring the functionality up to date, since the implementation was made about a year ago. 2. In the future cover the existing ToDos and limitations. Existing limitations: Listed in the README but might be outdated. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Project is covered by unit tests and Tempest tests. We need to know where to put the Tempest tests to make them available. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation of the API exists on Google's site. The rest can be covered in README.rst References ========== The existing stackforge project: https://github.com/stackforge/gce-api Kilo Design Summit notes: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/kilo-nova-summit-unconference Sister EC2 API project: https://github.com/stackforge/ec2-api https://review.openstack.org/#/c/147882

commit_message:
Nova specs doc for dynamic server groups - remove

This is the documentation for
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/dynamic-server-groups-remove

APIImpact
Change-Id: I1728e3b347b4ae0364785d167ac530bf4109f3bf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/87/136487/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================================== Dynamic Management of Server Groups - Remove a Server ====================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/dynamic-server-groups-remove This blueprint extends the functionality of "Server Groups" such that the virtual machines in the group can be removed at any time, instead of limiting it to virtual machine deletion time only. By providing this added bit of functionality, server groups become more operator-friendly and usable in many real-world scenarios. Problem description =================== Use Cases ---------- * As a cloud operator, I want to remove an instance from a server group (i.e., without having to delete the instance), so that I can update my groups as affinity rules change over time. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== A new action to be performed on server groups will be added to remove an instance from a server group. This will be added in the form of a new Nova API and a new Nova CLI. The API will be added to nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/server_groups.py. Also, a new delete_member() method will need to be added to the nova/objects/instance_group.py:InstanceGroup class that will call the existing Nova database API method instance_group_member_delete() to soft delete the instance in the INSTANCE_GROUP_MEMBER database table. Alternatives ------------ The alternative to this would be to retain the existing behavior where an instance will always belong to the given server group until the instance is deleted, and only then will the instance be removed from the server group. Data model impact ----------------- None. The existing instance group data models can be used. No additions needed. REST API impact --------------- New remove server API * Specification for the method * Removes a server from a server group * Method type: POST * Normal http response code: 200 * Expected error http response codes: * 400 - invalid request:: This response code will be returned if the request body is formatted incorrectly or a required parameter is missing from the request. * 404 - not found:: This response code will be returned if the server group does not exist or if the server passed in does not belong to the server group. * URL: /v2/{tenant_id}/os-server-groups/{ServerGroup_id}/action * Parameters: +----------------+-------+------------+-----------------------------------+ | Parameter | Style | Type | Description | +================+=======+============+===================================+ | tenant_id | URI | xsd:string | The ID for the tenant or | | | | | account in a multi-tenancy cloud. | +----------------+-------+------------+-----------------------------------+ | ServerGroup_id | URI | String | The server group ID. | +----------------+-------+------------+-----------------------------------+ | server_id | URI | capsi:UUID | The UUID for the server to remove | | | | | from the server group. | +----------------+-------+------------+-----------------------------------+ * JSON schema definition for the body data:: { "remove_server": { "server_id": "324dfb7d-f4a9-419a-9a19-237df04b443b" } } * JSON schema definition for the response data:: { "server_group": { "id": "5bbcc3c4-1da2-4437-a48a-66f15b1b13f9", "name": "test", "policies": [ "anti-affinity" ], "members": [], "metadata": {} } } * Policy Changes: Right now, the server group APIs only apply role checking at the compute_extension:server_groups level. A new action-level authorization will be added so that the Nova policy.json file has the ability to distinctly enumerate what roles can remove servers from a server group. The following action will be required in the policy to remove a server from a server group: * compute_extension:server_groups:remove_server Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- A Nova servergroup.deletmember notification will be created to be sent when a server is removed from a server group. Other end user impact --------------------- In addition to the API, the user will be able to use the Nova CLI to remove instances from a server group. The CLI will be of the form: * nova server-group-delete-server <id> <server> Where <id> represents the server group's identifier and <server> represents an instance's uuid or name. The uuid will be required in cases in which the name does not unambiguously identify a server. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jmulsow Other contributors: jwcroppe Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks: * Add 'remove a server from a server group' API to the v2 Server Group APIs. v2 extensions. * Add 'remove a server from a server group' API to the v3 Server Group APIs. * Add Nova CLI removing a server from a server group. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= This is a simple feature with no race conditions, so unit tests will provide complete testing coverage. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will be needed to the Nova APIs and Nova CLIs for the new 'remove server' action being added for server groups. References ========== Discussion on the openstack-dev mailing list: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-September/045636.html This topic was also discussed during the Nova Unconference session at the Kilo OpenStack Summit on November 6, 2014. https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/kilo-nova-summit-unconference

and prints diff in case of adding new lines withou UT coverage.

commit_message:
Imporve coverage job to make it voting

By default coverage job just generates cover directory with pretty HTML
report.

This change makes it voting:

It compares coverage of latest changes against that previous commit
and prints diff in case of adding new lines withou UT coverage.

As well it genereates HTML reports in cover/ dir

Change-Id: I1ac078ec67c92d0b8d6d3bb96f9ea79f61c5559a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cue refs/changes/20/177020/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {toxinidir}/cue/tests/scripts/coverage.sh {posargs}

commit_message:
glance provider: pick os_region_name from DEFAULT

In ::glance::api, os_region_name is set in DEFAULT which work for both
Juno & Kilo.

'glance_store' section has been introduced in Kilo which breaks Juno.
Until we decide our policy to manage master, let's use DEFAULT so both
releases work well.

Change-Id: I1c519146d3fe62f8c8fc8c2d85805db11af21e4c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-glance refs/changes/95/177395/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add statsd metrics support (not ready)

Change-Id: I29d477d0f5b2ff83320b77a75b96247ef0122aef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/02/103202/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Rackspace Hosting # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import random import socket import abc import six import time import logging from oslo.config import cfg from contextlib import closing metrics_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('statsd_host', default='127.0.0.1', help=''), cfg.IntOpt('statsd_port', default=8125, help=''), ] LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opts(metrics_opts, group='metrics') class time_call(object): def __init__(self, metricLogger, m_name): self._metricLogger = metricLogger self._m_name = m_name def __call__(self, f): def wrapped_f(*args, **kwargs): start = time.time() evaluated = f(*args, **kwargs) duration = time.time() - start self._metricLogger.gauge(self._m_name, duration) return evaluated return wrapped_f @six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class MetricLogger(object): def __init__(self, prefix, delimiter): self._prefix = prefix self._delimiter = delimiter def setPrefix(prefix): self._prefix = prefix def _getName(self, m_name): if self._prefix: return self._delimiter.join([self._prefix, m_name]) else: return m_name def gauge(self, m_name, m_value): self._gauge(self._getName(m_name), m_value) def counter(self, m_name, m_value, sample_rate=None): self._counter(self._getName(m_name), m_value, sample_rate) def timer(self, m_name, m_value): self._timer(self._getName(m_name), m_value) def histogram(self, m_name, m_value): self._histogram(self._getName(m_name), m_value) def meter(self, m_name, m_value): self._meter(self._getName(m_name), m_value) @abc.abstractmethod def _gauge(self, m_name, m_value): """""" @abc.abstractmethod def _counter(self, m_name, m_value, sample_rate=None): """""" @abc.abstractmethod def _timer(self, m_name, m_value): """""" @abc.abstractmethod def _histogram(self, m_name, m_value): """""" @abc.abstractmethod def _meter(self, m_name, m_value): """""" def getLogger(): return StatsdMetricLogger('', '.', CONF.metrics.statsd_host, CONF.metrics.statsd_port) class StatsdMetricLogger(MetricLogger): GAUGE_TYPE = 'g' COUNTER_TYPE = 'c' TIMER_TYPE = 'ms' HISTOGRAM_TYPE = 'h' METER_TYPE = 'm' def __init__(self, prefix, delimiter, host, port): super(StatsdMetricLogger, self).__init__(prefix, delimiter) self._host = host self._port = port self._target = (self._host, self._port) def _send(self, m_name, m_value, m_type, sample_rate=None): if sample_rate is None: metric = '%s:%s|%s' % (m_name, m_value, m_type) else: metric = '%s:%s|%s@%s' % (m_name, m_value, m_type, sample_rate) # Ideally, we'd cache a sending socket in self, but that # results in a socket getting shared by multiple green threads. with closing(self._open_socket()) as sock: return sock.sendto(metric, self._target) def _open_socket(self): return socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_DGRAM) def _gauge(self, m_name, m_value): return self._send(m_name, m_value, self.GAUGE_TYPE) def _counter(self, m_name, m_value, sample_rate=None): if sample_rate is None: return self._send(m_name, m_value, self.COUNTER_TYPE) elif 0 <= sample_rate and sample_rate <= 1 and random.random() < sample_rate: return self._send(m_name, m_value, self.COUNTER_TYPE, sample_rate) def _timer(self, m_name, m_value): return self._send(m_name, m_value, self.TIMER_TYPE) def _histogram(self, m_name, m_value): return self._send(m_name, m_value, self.HISTOGRAM_TYPE) def _meter(self, m_name, m_value): return self._send(m_name, m_value, self.METER_TYPE)

subject: Skip share tests when not supported by the driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-24 22:55:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/64a2e32b072570c77fefaf9894905e603ebae993', 'message': "Skip share tests when not supported by the driver

Although the driver states it doesn't support server shares
in the configuration file via the driver_handles_share_servers property,
they are still being executed and failing by tempest.

According to the manila tempest configuration, the tempest.conf
also needs multitenancy configuration set to false so that they are skipped [1]

This issue is not being caught in the gate because the default lvm driver
supports both modes. This change uses the job configuration to ensure both
settings are aligned.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Manila/docs/HOWTO_use_tempest_with_manila#Option_.22multitenancy_enabled.22

Change-Id: I56c56d251982f7b687483fe380669a64c1b05e09
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-04-25 17:39:06.000000000', 'files': ['contrib/ci/pre_test_hook.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/478687e7c4f264898cc86bffc82c766e56a32a06', 'message': "Skip share tests when not supported by the driver

Although the driver states it doesn't support server shares
in the configuration file via the driver_handles_share_servers property,
they are still being executed and failing by tempest.

This issue is not being caught in the gate because the default driver
supports both modes. This change uses the job configuration to ensure both
settings are aligned for the tests run after the pre_test_hook is called
but before the post_test_hook is called.

According to the manila tempest configuration, the tempest.conf
also needs multitenancy configuration set to false so that they are skipped [1]

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Manila/docs/HOWTO_use_tempest_with_manila#Option_.22multitenancy_enabled.22

Change-Id: I56c56d251982f7b687483fe380669a64c1b05e09
"}]
commit_message:
Skip share tests when not supported by the driver

Although the driver states it doesn't support server shares
in the configuration file via the driver_handles_share_servers property,
they are still being executed and failing by tempest.

This issue is not being caught in the gate because the default driver
supports both modes. This change uses the job configuration to ensure both
settings are aligned for the tests run after the pre_test_hook is called
but before the post_test_hook is called.

According to the manila tempest configuration, the tempest.conf
also needs multitenancy configuration set to false so that they are skipped [1]

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Manila/docs/HOWTO_use_tempest_with_manila#Option_.22multitenancy_enabled.22

Change-Id: I56c56d251982f7b687483fe380669a64c1b05e09
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/80/177480/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Also tell tempest whether or not share servers is supported iniset $BASE/new/tempest/etc/tempest.conf share multitenancy_enabled $driver_handles_share_servers

commit_message:
V2:cinder create --image option doesn't work

In create volume help, --image optional parameter is allowed to
be passed to create volume, but even after passing valid image ID
or NAME, volume is created without image.

Assigned image  parameter to the image_ref to fix this issue.

Closes-Bug: 1447589
Change-Id: I21b8a51451a2caf230ca04103b2d573d1aa966b4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/79/177479/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: image_ref = args.image_id or args.image or args.image_ref

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-12-09 03:58:02.000000000', 'files': ['specs/kilo/ipv6-floatingip.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/3a2190662c3eef0f33225b2de9a57d6db86fa38e', 'message': 'Support Floatingip for IPv6

Change-Id: Ibd4e444923c91235783b027b6ece0dd392197690

commit_message:
Support Floatingip for IPv6

Change-Id: Ibd4e444923c91235783b027b6ece0dd392197690
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/31/139731/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================== IPv6 Router and DVR =================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ipv6-floatingip What is a floating IP? In IPv4, a floating IP is an IPv4 address that can be associated with a VM. The VM can then use the IP address to communicate with the internet. The IP address is not assigned to the VM's network interface, however. IPv4 router uses NAT to perform address translation between the VM's private IP address and the floating IP. In addition, floatingips are allocated from a public network that can be shared by multiple tenants. Can IPv6 use the same floating IP APIs even though NAT is not desirable? In this specification, we'll explore how to use the same API to provide public access for IPv6 tenant network. Problem Description =================== The following depicts a reference IPv4 implementation on a centralized neutron router running on a l3 enabled node. :: +----+ +----+ +----+ | | | | | | | VM | | VM | +----------+ | VM | | | | | | | +--+-+ +--+-+ +--+-+ | SG | SG | SG +-------+------------ +---+-------------------+------+ | Tenant Private Network +---------+--------+ 10.0.0.0/24 | Neutron qr-xxx | | Router 10.0.0.1 | | | | NAT | +---------+--------+ | qg-xxx | 172.24.1.1 +------------------------+--------------------------+ Public Network 172.24.1.0/24 * A neutron L3 node is a node where neutron l3 agent is running. A scheduler is responsible to place a router to a L3 node. * Each VM gets a private IP address * Each VM has a default route with the next hop to be 10.0.0.1 *VM Without floating IP* * Packets to/from the public network will perform NAT. The source IP of outgoing packets will be changed to 172.24.1.1 before they go out of qg-xxx. The Packets coming into qg-xxx with destination IP 172.24.1.1 will get translated to the corresponding 10.0.0.x before it's sent to the qr-xxx router port. * With source NAT, it's not possible to initiate communications from the public network to the VM *VM With floating IP* * Packets to/from the public network will perform NAT. The source IP of outgoing packets will be changed to the floating IP associated with the VM before they go out of qg-xxx. The packets coming into qg-xxx with the destination IP being the floating IP will get translated to the VM's 10.0.0.x before it's sent to the qr-xxx router port. * Since the VM is associated with a floating IP, communications initiated from the public network to the VM is now possible with proper security rules added. In any case, Default security group rules makes sure that no IP and Mac spoofing is possible, and communications initiated from outside the VM will only be allowed with source IPs in a well-defined ip set that basically includes the VMs on the same network. In IPv6, to gain public access, a tenant can use GUA addresses in its network [IPV6_DVR]_. The GUA prefix is exclusively given to the tenant network, and can not be used by other tenant networks. Given a single /64 prefix has almost inexhaustible addresses, it's desirable and possible, through, to share the same GUA prefix among the tenant networks. It's equally desirable to use the same floatingip API as used by IPv4 network today to support the shared GUA prefix, while giving ULA prefixes to the tenant networks. In the case of neutron IPv4 network, private addresses are used in the tenant network. The APIs floatingip-create and floatingip-associate are used to create and associate a floatingip with a fixed-ip which is allocated from a tenant data network to a neutron port. However the floatingip is not physically assigned to the neutron port (or rather not assigned physically to the VM's interface). The VM's interface has only the address from the tenant's network. Therefore, NAT has to be performed in a neutron router between the two IPs. NAT is considered undesirable for IPv6 [RFC4864]_, but its deployment may be likely in some cases [RFC5902]_. Therefore, in this specification, we'll not prevent the user from using IPv6 NAT while using floatingip. With NAT in the picture for IPv6, there might be several ways to implement the neutron floatingip API: * Avoid NAT completely. In this case, VMs with ULA addreses only will not be able to access the internet unless other mechanisms (such as tunneling, proxy server, etc) is deployed in the tenant network. If a neutron port is associated with a floatingip, the floatingip will be physically assigned to the VM's interface. * Use NAT for VMs without floatingip, but don't use it if a VM has a floatingip. In this case, all the VMs will have internet access by default. If a neutron port is associated with a floatingip, the floatingip will be physically assigned to the VM's interface. * Use NAT exclusively. In this case, it's working exactly the same as in IPv4. It's also possible to support floatingip with IPv6 DVR [IPV6_DVR]_. Proposed Change =============== Since the release of linux kernel 3.7, ip6tables started supporting NAT targets. Since IPv6 floatingip using NAT is similar in nature with IPv4 floatingip, we'll not focus our discussion on it in this specification. Rather, we'll focus on the first two methods in implementing the floatingip API for IPv6. Currently, the floatingip API is only supported for IPv4. There are also incorrect behavior in dual stack that's being addressed in this patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/131145/. In that patch, IPv6 is completely blocked from using floatingips. Enhancement is needed in the API implementation so that addresss families should match between the private address and it's associated floatingip. This means an IPv6 floatingip cannot be associated with a IPv4 private address, or vice versa. IPv6 Floatingip Reference Model ------------------------------- In the following diagram, each VM has two ipv6 addresses (in addition to the LLA), one is a ULA from the prefix fd00:1234::/64, and the other is a GUA from the prefix 2001:abcd::/64. It depicts a reference implementation when a floatingip is physically assigned to the VM's interface. Communications between the VMs on the same tenant network uses the ULA address, while communications with the external world uses the GUA address. There are two ways to assign a floatingip to a VM's interface automatically: DHCPv6 or RA. Neutron uses dnsmasq as the default dhcp driver, and uses radvd for RA. :: +-----------------+ +-----------------+ | VM | | VM | | | | | | fd00:1234::1/64 | ... | fd00:1234::2/64 | | 2001:abcd::1/64 | | 2001:abcd::2/64 | +-------+---------+ +------+----------+ | | | | fd00:1234::/64 +------+------------+----------+------------------+ | Tenant Private Network | +------------------+-------------------+ | IPv6 qr-xxx | | Router fe80::21b:21ff:febf:4c8 | | | | RADVD, NDP, Host Routes | | | | qg-xxx | | fe80::f816:3eff:fe94:f6f1 | +------------------+-------------------+ | | +-------------------+------------------------+ | Public Network | +------------+----------+ |fe80::21c:3abb:eecf:5c9| | upstream | | router | +-----------------------+ First of all, it should be clarified that the prefix 2001:abcd::/64 used for floatingip belongs to the public network. In the above diagram, though, it seems that it belongs to the tenant network as well since it's a /64 prefix. Ideally, a VM with a floatingip should be given a /128 host address. For example, in the above diagram, the VMs should be given 2001:abcd::1/128 and 2001:abcd::2/128, respectively. Although assigning a /128 address to an interface can be done manually, it's not always possible to do so automatically with DHCPv6 or RA with the following reasons: * DHCPv6 leases individual ip addresses without the ability to specify the prefix length. Some DHCPv6 clients brute-forcely assign a /64 netmask to the address for ethernet interfaces. * A /128 host address can be advertised to a VM with targeted RA. However, the RA standards specifies that the received prefix length plus the length of the interface ID must be equal to 128. Given that an ethernet interface ID's length is 64, only a /64 prefix is acceptable. Therefore, it leaves no other choice than assigning the floatingip with /64 prefix length to a VM's interface. Since the prefix 2001:abcd::/64 belongs to the public network that can be shared among neutron routers and tenants, we need a mechanism so that communications between the floatingips are possible. Fortunately, IPv6 NDP makes it possible for VMs with floatingips to communicate across the tenant network boundaries. Details will be described later in this specification. Delivery of Floatingip to a VM ------------------------------ As described in above, there are two methods to deliver a floatingip to a VM: DHCPv6 or RA. Which method is used depends on the IPv6 subnet that's created for the public network. If stateful address assignment is specified in the subnet, then DHCPv6 is used to deliver the address; if SLAAC is specified in the subnet, then RA is used. When RA is used, a separate RADVD daemon is instantiated to deliver floatingip addresses to its targeted receipient. When DHCPv6 is used, the default driver needs to be enhanced to support floatingip addresses in the dnsmasq config file. Neutron Router Setup -------------------- In the simple case, for traffic destined to the internet, the router has a default route going out of the gq-xxx interface. For incoming traffic destined to a specific floatingip, host route needs to be installed in the neutron router. As illustrated in the above diagram, the following routes will be installed in the neutron router: :: Destination Next Hop If 2001.abcd::1/64 :: gr-xxx 2001.abcd::2/64 :: gr-xxx 2001.abcd::/64 :: qg-xxx ::/0 fe80::21c:3abb:eecf:5c9 qg-xxx A cloud may use a shared router for all the tenants. It's also possible to support multiple routers in a cloud that shares the same public network. To support that configuration, on each router: * Install a route for 2001.abcd::/64 with the egress interface as qg-xxx. Note that no nexthop should be specified since the public network with the prefix 2001.abcd::/64 is a shared LAN. * Enable proxy_ndp on the qg-xxx interface * For each floatingip that is allocated to the VMs whose next hop is this router, add a neighbour proxy on the qg-xxx interface With NDP enabled on each router, the upstream router will be able to deliver traffic to the right neutron router which then forwards it to the destination VM. A more complex case involves communications among the tenants using floatingips. This is possible since a VM under one tenant may request service from another VM belonging to a different tenant. Note that as indicated in above, /64 netmask has to be used for the floatingip inside the VM. Therefore, ND will run first to discover the neighbor to a particular destination, for instance, 2001.abcd::xxxx. Because the address 2001.abcd::xxxx is not on the same tenant network, however, to send traffic to that address, the router has to pick up the responsibility acting as the next hop to that destination. Therefore, proxy_ndb needs to be enabled on the qr-xxx interface. With IPv6, a proxy entry to a particular destination must be installed in order for the NDP to answer ND request to that destination. This means, to be able to talk to each other between all the VMs with floatingips, on each qr-xxx interface that is on a particular tenenat network, all the floatingips allocated to the other tenant networks sharing the same public network may have to be proxied. This may pose a scalability issue. The good news is that not all VMs talk to each other. Therefore, it's possible to install a proxy entry as needed basis. In this specification, we assume that the full-meshed proxies are installed for simplicity. A separate blueprint will be written in the near future to develop a NDP daemon that answers ND requests based on information that are stored in the neutron database. With full-meshed ND proxy entries installed on all the routers, when a VM sends a packet to another VM that is on a different tenant network, * The packet arrives at the qr-xxx interface on the VM's default router * The router forwards the packet based on its routing table. There will be two cases: * If the router has a /128 entry for the destination with qr-yyy as the egress, and if there is no established neighbor for the destination, it sends ND out of qr-yyy for the destination 2001.abcd::xxxx, and when the neighbor entry is established, forwards the packet out of the qr-yyy interface. Otherwise, * there should be a route entry for the network 2001.abcd::/64. If there doesn't exist a neighbor entry for 2001.abcd::xxxx, it sends a ND request out of qg-xxx interface. The destination router which has a proxy entry for 2001.abcd::xxxx will answer the request. Once the neighbor entry is established, forwards the packet out of the qg-xxx interface. When the destination router receives the packet, there should be an /128 entry in its routing table. If there is no established neighbor for the destination, it sends ND out of the egress interface (say qr-zzz). Once the neighbor is established, forwards the packet out of the qr-zzz interface. IPv6 DVR with floating IP ------------------------- In last section, we talked about the router setup for a centralized neutron router. The same can be applied to IPv6 DVR setup. In the case of DVR, if a floatingip is allocated to a VM, then that floatingip needs to be handled by the VM's default router. A Cloud With Mixed GUA and Floating IP -------------------------------------- Not sure why it would be used, but it's possible to mix GUA and floating IPs in an IPv6 router. All Floatingip Neutron Network? ------------------------------- Is it possible not to assign a ULA address to the tenant network, but assign floatingips only? It's surely possible given in above how the floatingip can be implemented. We'll not cover this in length in this spec, but maybe in the future this can be further explored if such a use case arises. Data Model Impact ----------------- TBD REST API Impact --------------- First of all, user should be allowed to specify which one out of the three floatingip implementations is desired. This can be done by adding a new option into the neutron network API. :: neutron net-create <name> -- --router:ipv6-fip=[nat|no-nat|partial-nat] By default, no-nat is assumed. If ipv6-fip is partial-nat, then for VMs without floatingips, NAT will be used. If ipv6-fip is nat, then floatingip will not be assigned physically to the VM's interface, and NAT will be performed on ULA addresses that belong to the tenant network. The address delivery method is specified in the IPv6 subnet that belongs to the public network. Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- TBD Performance Impact ------------------ Targeted RAs may be sent to deliver floatingips to VMs. No performance impact is expected ND proxy on the qr-xxx interface may have a negative impact on system performance. A NDP deamon to add NDP entry on demand will be addressed in a separate blueprint in the near future. IPv6 Impact ----------- This specification specifies an implementation of floatingip API for IPv6 Other Deployer Impact --------------------- TBD Developer Impact ---------------- TBD Community Impact ---------------- TBD Alternatives ------------ TBD Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: baoli Other contributors: dboik Work Items ---------- * Floatingip API implementation to support IPv6 * RA deamon to deliver floatingip with targeted RA * dhcp agent enhancement to process floatingips for IPv6 * L3 agent change to support IPv6 floatingip * router namespace setup to support forwarding * Develop test cases * Tempest tests TBD Dependencies ============ . Multiple Prefix Support [MULTI_PRE]_ . Kilo refactoring and restructuring the l3 agent [REFAC_L3]_ . IPv6 Router and DVR [IPV6_DVR]_ Testing ======= TBD Tempest Tests ------------- TBD Functional Tests ---------------- TBD API Tests --------- TBD Documentation Impact ==================== TBD User Documentation ------------------ User guide to neutron router needs to be updated Developer Documentation ----------------------- API changes need to be documented. References ========== .. [IPV6_DVR] `IPv6 Router and DVR <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/136878/>`_ .. [MULTI_PRE] `Multiple IPv6 Prefix Support <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/98217/>`_ .. [REFAC_L3] `Kilo refactoring and restructuring the l3 agent <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/131535/>`_ .. [RFC4389] `Neighbor Discovery Proxies (ND Proxy) <https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4389>`_ .. [RFC4291] `IP Version 6 Addressing Architecture <https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4291>`_ .. [RFC4864] `Local Network Protection for IPv6 <http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4864>`_ .. [RFC5902] `IAB Thoughts on IPv6 Network Address Translation <http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5902>`_

commit_message:
Improve angular test dependency versions

Currently our angular test dependencies are pinned, and pinned rather
low.  I'd like to both increase the versions numbers and unpin the
version numbers.

npm allows some pretty cool version-number-controls:
https://docs.npmjs.com/files/package.json#dependencies

I claim that since we're dealing with dev-dependencies, we are more than
ok using the "^" or "~" syntax.

NOTE: karma-jasmine >= 0.3 requires a separate install of jasmine-core.

Also, upgrading the jasmine version will allow us to run a single
test-suite or test:
describe -> fdescribe
it -> fit

Change-Id: I38cf1df84635745bfb4001492baf563b7c112a35
